entities.description: The Quanzhen School, also known as Completion of Authenticity, Complete Reality, and Complete Perfection is currently the most dominant branch of Taoism in continental China. It originated in Northern China in 1170 under the Jin dynasty (1115–1234). One of its founders was the Taoist Wang Chongyang, who lived in the early Jin. When the Mongols invaded the Song dynasty (960–1279) in 1254, the Quanz

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferdinand II of León (b. 1137)

entities.title: Ferdinand II of León
entities.description: Ferdinand II, was a member of the Castilian cadet branch of the House of Ivrea and King of León and Galicia from 1157 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis I, Duke of Bourbon (b. 1279)

entities.title: Louis I, Duke of Bourbon
entities.description: Louis I, called the Lame was Count of Clermont-en-Beauvaisis and La Marche and the first Duke of Bourbon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hadım Sinan Pasha, Ottoman politician, 32nd Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire (b. ?)

entities.title: Hadım Sinan Pasha
entities.description: Hadım Sinan Pasha was Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire from 1516 to 1517. He was of Bosnian descent.

entities.title: Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire
entities.description: The Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire was the de facto prime minister of the sultan in the Ottoman Empire, with absolute power of attorney and, in principle, dismissible only by the sultan himself in the classical period, before the Tanzimat reforms, or until the 1908 Revolution. He held the imperial seal and could convene all other viziers to attend to affairs of the state in the Imperial Counci

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernhard Knipperdolling, German religious leader (b. 1495)

entities.title: Bernhard Knipperdolling
entities.description: Bernhard Knipperdolling was a German leader of the Münster Anabaptists. He was also known as Bernd or Berndt Knipperdollinck or Knypperdollynck or Bertrand Knipperdoling; his birth name was van Stockem.

heading: Deaths
txt: John of Leiden, Anabaptist leader from the Dutch city of Leiden (b. 1509)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset, English general and politician, Lord High Treasurer of England (b. 1500)

entities.title: Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset
entities.description: Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset PC, also known as Edward Semel, was the eldest surviving brother of Queen Jane Seymour (d. 1537), the third wife of King Henry VIII. He was Lord Protector of England from 1547 to 1549 during the minority of his nephew King Edward VI (1547–1553). Despite his popularity with the common people, his policies often angered the gentry and he was overthrown.

entities.title: Lord High Treasurer
entities.description: The post of Lord High Treasurer or Lord Treasurer was an English government position and has been a British government position since the Acts of Union of 1707. A holder of the post would be the third-highest-ranked Great Officer of State, below the Lord High Steward and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wang Zhi, Chinese pirate

entities.title: Wang Zhi (pirate)
entities.description: Wang Zhi, art name Wufeng (五峰), was a Chinese pirate lord of the 16th century, one of the chief named and known figures among the wokou pirates prevalent during the reign of the Jiajing Emperor. Originally a salt merchant, Wang Zhi turned to smuggling during the Ming dynasty's period of maritime prohibitions banning all private overseas trade, and eventually became the head of a pirate syndicate s

heading: Deaths
txt: James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault (b. 1516)

entities.title: James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault
entities.description: James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault, 2nd Earl of Arran, was a regent for Mary, Queen of Scots, from 1543 to 1554.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cristofano Malvezzi, Italian organist and composer (b. 1547)

entities.title: Cristofano Malvezzi
entities.description: Cristofano Malvezzi was an Italian organist and composer of the late Renaissance. He was one of the most famous composers in the city of Florence during a time of transition to the Baroque style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Shah Jahan, Mughal emperor (b. 1592)

entities.title: Shah Jahan
entities.description: Shahab-ud-din Muhammad Khurram, better known by his regnal name, Shah Jahan, was the fifth Mughal emperor, and reigned from 1628 to 1658. Under his reign, the Mughal Empire reached the peak of its cultural glory. Although an able military commander, Shah Jahan is best remembered for his architectural achievements. His reign ushered in the golden age of Mughal architecture. Shah Jahan commissioned

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Xaver Josef von Unertl, Bavarian politician (b. 1675)

entities.title: Franz Xaver Josef von Unertl
entities.description: Franz Xaver Josef Baron von Unertl was a Bavarian politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Carteret, 2nd Earl Granville, English politician, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (b. 1690)

entities.title: John Carteret, 2nd Earl Granville
entities.description: John Carteret, 2nd Earl Granville, 7th Seigneur of Sark,, commonly known by his earlier title Lord Carteret, was a British statesman and Lord President of the Council from 1751 to 1763; he worked extremely closely with the Prime Minister of the country, Spencer Compton, Earl of Wilmington, in order to manage the various factions of the Government. He was Seigneur of Sark from 1715 to 1720 when he

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland
entities.description: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, or more formally Lord Lieutenant General and General Governor of Ireland, was the title of the chief governor of Ireland from the Williamite Wars of 1690 until the Partition of Ireland in 1922. This spanned the Kingdom of Ireland (1541–1800) and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland (1801–1922). The office, under its various names, was often more generally kno

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Gottlob Lehmann, German meteorologist and geologist (b. 1719)

entities.title: Johann Gottlob Lehmann (scientist)
entities.description: Johann Gottlob Lehmann was a German mineralogist and geologist noted for his work and research contributions to the geologic record leading to the development of stratigraphy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jeremiah Dixon, English surveyor and astronomer (b. 1733)

entities.title: Jeremiah Dixon
entities.description: Jeremiah Dixon FRS was an English surveyor and astronomer who is best known for his work with Charles Mason, from 1763 to 1767, in determining what was later called the Mason–Dixon line.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claudius Smith, American guerrilla leader (b. 1736)

heading: Deaths
txt: Lewis Morris, American judge and politician (b. 1726)

entities.title: Lewis Morris
entities.description: Lewis Morris was an American landowner and developer from Morrisania, New York, presently part of Bronx County. He signed the U.S. Declaration of Independence as a delegate to the Continental Congress from New York.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Friedrich Blumenbach, German physician, physiologist, and anthropologist (b. 1752)

entities.title: Johann Friedrich Blumenbach
entities.description: Johann Friedrich Blumenbach was a German physician, naturalist, physiologist, and anthropologist. He is considered to be a main founder of zoology and anthropology as comparative, scientific disciplines. He was also important as a race theorist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vincent Pallotti, Italian missionary and saint (b. 1795)

entities.title: Vincent Pallotti
entities.description: Vincent Pallotti was an Italian ecclesiastic and a saint. Born in Rome, he was the founder of the Society of the Catholic Apostolate later to be known as the "Pious Society of Missions". The original name was restored in 1947. He is buried in the church of San Salvatore in Onda. He is considered the forerunner of Catholic Action. His feast day is 22 January.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anthony Durnford, Irish colonel (b. 1830)

entities.title: Anthony Durnford
entities.description: Lieutenant-Colonel Anthony William Durnford was an Irish career British Army officer of the Royal Engineers who served in the Anglo-Zulu War. Breveted colonel, Durnford is mainly known for his defeat by the Zulus at the Battle of Isandlwana, which was a disaster for the British Army.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Pulleine, English colonel (b. 1838)

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph P. Bradley, American lawyer and jurist (b. 1813)

entities.title: Joseph P. Bradley
entities.description: Joseph Philo Bradley was an American jurist best known for his service on the United States Supreme Court, and on the Electoral Commission that decided the disputed 1876 presidential election.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Edward Hughes, Welsh-American physicist, co-invented the microphone (b. 1831)

entities.title: David Edward Hughes
entities.description: David Edward Hughes, was a British-American inventor, practical experimenter, and professor of music known for his work on the printing telegraph and the microphone. He is generally considered to have been born in London but his family moved around that time so he may have been born in Corwen, Wales. His family moved to the U.S. while he was a child and he became a professor of music in Kentucky.

entities.title: Microphone
entities.description: A microphone, colloquially called a mic or mike, is a device – a transducer – that converts sound into an electrical signal. Microphones are used in many applications such as telephones, hearing aids, public address systems for concert halls and public events, motion picture production, live and recorded audio engineering, sound recording, two-way radios, megaphones, radio and television broadcast

heading: Deaths
txt: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom (b. 1819)

entities.title: Queen Victoria
entities.description: Victoria was Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 20 June 1837 until her death in 1901. Known as the Victorian era, her reign of 63 years and seven months was longer than any previous British monarch. It was a period of industrial, political, scientific, and military change within the United Kingdom, and was marked by a great expansion of the British Empire. In 1876, Parli

heading: Deaths
txt: Emil Erlenmeyer, German chemist and academic (b. 1825)

heading: Deaths
txt: George Streeter, American captain and businessman (b. 1837)

entities.title: George Streeter
entities.description: George Wellington "Cap" Streeter was an American who became infamous in Chicago for his real estate schemes and oftentimes bizarre eccentricity. From 1886 to 1921, Streeter, often through forgery and other manipulative means, attempted to lay claim to 186 acres (0.75 km2) of Lake Michigan shoreline from various owners. Failing in his efforts to defraud wealthy landowners, he turned to selling the

heading: Deaths
txt: Fredrik Bajer, Danish educator and politician, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1837)

entities.title: Fredrik Bajer
entities.description: Fredrik Bajer was a Danish writer, teacher, and pacifist politician who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1908 together with Klas Pontus Arnoldson.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Benedict XV (b. 1854)

heading: Deaths
txt: Camille Jordan, French mathematician and academic (b. 1838)

heading: Deaths
txt: Fanny Bullock Workman, American geographer and mountain climber (b. 1859)

entities.title: Fanny Bullock Workman
entities.description: Fanny Bullock Workman was an American geographer, cartographer, explorer, travel writer, and mountaineer, notably in the Himalayas. She was one of the first female professional mountaineers; she not only explored but also wrote about her adventures. She set several women's altitude records, published eight travel books with her husband, and championed women's rights and women's suffrage.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Ford Rhodes, American historian and author (b. 1848)

entities.title: James Ford Rhodes
entities.description: James Ford Rhodes, was an American industrialist and historian born in Cleveland, Ohio. After earning a fortune in the iron, coal, and steel industries by 1885, he retired from business. He devoted his life to historical research and publishing a seven-volume history of the United States beginning in 1850; his work was published from 1893 to 1906. He published an eighth volume in 1920. His work, H

heading: Deaths
txt: R. C. Lehmann, English journalist, author, and politician (b. 1856)

entities.title: R. C. Lehmann
entities.description: Rudolph Chambers "R.C." Lehmann was an English writer and Liberal Party politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1906 to 1910. As a writer he was best known for three decades in which he was a major contributor to Punch as well as founding editor of Granta magazine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stephen Mather, American businessman and conservationist, co-founded the Thorkildsen-Mather Borax Company (b. 1867)

entities.title: Stephen Mather
entities.description: Stephen Tyng Mather was an American industrialist and conservationist who was the first director of the National Park Service. As president and owner of Thorkildsen-Mather Borax Company he became a millionaire. With his friend the journalist Robert Sterling Yard, Mather led a publicity campaign to promote the creation of a unified federal agency to oversee National Parks administration, which was

entities.title: Thorkildsen-Mather Borax Company
entities.description: Thorkildsen-Mather Borax Company was a borax mining company founded in 1898 by Stephen Mather and Thomas Thorkildsen. The two men were both employees of Francis Marion "Borax" Smith's Pacific Coast Borax Company, but they left the company to form this new company and went into direct competition with their former boss. The company was later renamed Sterling Borax. Francis Marion Smith subsequently

heading: Deaths
txt: László Batthyány-Strattmann, Hungarian physician and ophthalmologist (b. 1870)

entities.title: László Batthyány-Strattmann
entities.description: László Batthyány-Strattmann was a Hungarian aristocrat and physician. Until 1914, he was known as László Batthyány. A devout Roman Catholic, he became known as the "doctor of the poor" and was beatified by the church in 2003.

heading: Deaths
txt: Else Lasker-Schüler, German poet and playwright (b. 1869)

entities.title: Else Lasker-Schüler
entities.description: Else Lasker-Schüler was a German-Jewish poet and playwright famous for her bohemian lifestyle in Berlin and her unique poetic genius. She was one of the few women affiliated with the Expressionist movement. Lasker-Schüler fled Nazi Germany and lived out the rest of her life in Jerusalem.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Thomas Walsh, American author, poet, and playwright (b. 1891)

entities.title: William Thomas Walsh
entities.description: William Thomas Walsh, was an historian, educator and author; he was also an accomplished violinist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alan Hale, Sr., American actor and director (b. 1892)

entities.title: Alan Hale, Sr.
entities.description: Alan Hale Sr. was an American film actor and director, best remembered for his many character roles, in particular as a frequent sidekick of Errol Flynn, as well as films supporting Lon Chaney, Wallace Beery, Douglas Fairbanks, James Cagney, Clark Gable, Cary Grant, Humphrey Bogart, and Ronald Reagan. Hale's career in film lasted 40 years.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harald Bohr, Danish mathematician and footballer (b. 1887)

entities.title: Harald Bohr
entities.description: Harald August Bohr was a Danish mathematician and footballer. After receiving his doctorate in 1910, Bohr became an eminent mathematician, founding the field of almost periodic functions. His brother was the Nobel Prize-winning physicist Niels Bohr. He was a member of the Danish national football team for the 1908 Summer Olympics, where he won a silver medal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lawson Robertson, Scottish-American sprinter and high jumper (b. 1883)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jonni Myyrä, Finnish-American athlete (b. 1892)

entities.title: Jonni Myyrä
entities.description: Joonas "Jonni" Myyrä was a Finnish athlete who competed at the 1912, 1920 and 1924 Olympics. In 1912, he finished eighth in the javelin throw. At the 1920 Olympics his left arm was fractured in a warm-up accident – the spear thrown by James Lincoln struck Myyrä while he was resting on the grass. Nevertheless, Myyrä won the javelin event with an Olympic record of 65.78 meters. He also finished 12th

heading: Deaths
txt: Ralph Barton Perry, American philosopher and academic (b. 1876)

entities.title: Ralph Barton Perry
entities.description: Ralph Barton Perry was an American philosopher. He was a strident moral idealist who stated in 1909 that, to him, idealism meant "to interpret life consistently with ethical, scientific, and metaphysical truth." Perry's viewpoints on religion stressed the notion that religious thinking possessed legitimacy should it exist within a framework accepting of human reason and social progress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mike Hawthorn, English race car driver (b. 1929)

entities.title: Mike Hawthorn
entities.description: John Michael Hawthorn was a British racing driver. He became the United Kingdom's first Formula One World Champion driver in 1958, whereupon he announced his retirement, having been profoundly affected by the death of his teammate and friend Peter Collins two months earlier in the 1958 German Grand Prix. Hawthorn also won the 1955 24 Hours of Le Mans, but was haunted by his involvement in the disa

heading: Deaths
txt: Marc Blitzstein, American pianist and composer (b. 1905)

entities.title: Marc Blitzstein
entities.description: Marcus Samuel Blitzstein, was an American composer, lyricist, and librettist. He won national attention in 1937 when his pro-union musical The Cradle Will Rock, directed by Orson Welles, was shut down by the Works Progress Administration. He is known for The Cradle Will Rock and for his Off-Broadway translation/adaptation of The Threepenny Opera by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill. His works also inc

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Marshall, English actor (b. 1890)

entities.title: Herbert Marshall
entities.description: Herbert Brough Falcon Marshall was an English stage, screen and radio actor who starred in many popular and well-regarded Hollywood films in the 1930s and 1940s. After a successful theatrical career in the United Kingdom and North America, he became an in-demand Hollywood leading man, frequently appearing in romantic melodramas and occasional comedies. In his later years, he turned to character ac

heading: Deaths
txt: Duke Kahanamoku, American swimmer and water polo player (b. 1890)

entities.title: Duke Kahanamoku
entities.description: Duke Paoa Kahinu Mokoe Hulikohola Kahanamoku was an American and Native Hawaiian competition swimmer who popularized the ancient Hawaiian sport of surfing. He was born towards the end of the Kingdom of Hawaii, just before the overthrow, living into statehood as a United States citizen. He was a five-time Olympic medalist in swimming. Duke was also a Scottish Rite Freemason, a Shriner, a law enforc

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Frank Guggenheim, American businessman and publisher, co-founded Newsday (b. 1890)

entities.title: Harry Frank Guggenheim
entities.description: Harry Frank Guggenheim was an American businessman, diplomat, publisher, philanthropist, aviator, and horseman.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lyndon B. Johnson, American lieutenant and politician, 36th President of the United States (b. 1908)

entities.title: Lyndon B. Johnson
entities.description: Lyndon Baines Johnson, often referred to by his initials LBJ, was an American politician who served as the 36th president of the United States from 1963 to 1969, and previously as 37th vice president from 1961 to 1963. He assumed the presidency following the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. A Democrat from Texas, Johnson was also a United States representative and later majority leader

entities.title: President of the United States
entities.description: The president of the United States (POTUS) is the head of state and head of government of the United States of America. The president directs the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the United States Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrew George Burry, Swiss-American businessman and philanthropist (b. 1873)

entities.title: Andrew George Burry
entities.description: Andrew George Burry was a businessman, manufacturer and philanthropist. Born in Undervillier, Switzerland, he emigrated to the United States in 1884. Burry founded the Wayne Paper Box and Printing Corp. in 1898, and was also the founder and President of the National Paper Box Manufacturing Association(s) in 1917 - 1918, and 1926 - 1928.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ibrahim bin Abdullah Al Suwaiyel, Saudi Arabian diplomat (b. 1916)

entities.title: Ibrahim bin Abdullah Al Suwaiyel
entities.description: Sheikh Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Abdulaziz bin Abdullah Al Suwaiyel was a Saudi Arabian statesman and diplomat who most notably served as the minister of foreign affairs from 1960 to 1962. Appointed on 22 December 1960 by King Saud, he succeeded the future king, Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud and was succeeded by him again on 16 March 1961. He was noted for being the first non-royal to hold the posit

heading: Deaths
txt: Oliver Leese, English general (b. 1894)

entities.title: Oliver Leese
entities.description: Lieutenant-General Sir Oliver William Hargreaves Leese, 3rd Baronet, was a senior British Army officer who saw distinguished active service during both the world wars. He is most notable during the Second World War for commanding XXX Corps in North Africa and Sicily, serving under General Sir Bernard Montgomery, before going on to command the Eighth Army in the Italian Campaign throughout most of

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Sutcliffe, English cricketer and soldier (b. 1894)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ali Hassan Salameh, Palestinian rebel leader (b. 1940)

entities.title: Ali Hassan Salameh
entities.description: Ali Hassan Salameh was the chief of operations—code name Abu Hassan—for Black September, the organization responsible for the 1972 Munich massacre and other terror attacks. He was also the founder of Force 17. He was assassinated by Mossad in January 1979 as part of Operation Wrath of God.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yitzhak Baer, German-Israeli historian and academic (b. 1888)

entities.title: Yitzhak Baer
entities.description: Yitzhak Baer was a German-Israeli historian and an expert on medieval Spanish Jewish history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ishtiaq Hussain Qureshi, Pakistani historian and academic (b. 1903)

entities.title: Ishtiaq Hussain Qureshi
entities.description: Ishtiaq Hussain Qureshi popularly known as I.H. Qureshi), SP, HI, was a Pakistani historian, scholar, writer, and a professor of political history, first at the University of the Punjab and then at the Karachi University. Apart from his work as an academic historian he was also a well-known playwright.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduardo Frei Montalva, Chilean lawyer and politician, 28th President of Chile (b. 1911)

entities.title: Eduardo Frei Montalva
entities.description: Eduardo Nicanor Frei Montalva was a Chilean political leader. In his long political career, he was Minister of Public Works, president of his Christian Democratic Party, senator, President of the Senate, and the 28th president of Chile from 1964 to 1970. His eldest son, Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle, also became president of Chile (1994–2000).

entities.title: President of Chile
entities.description: The president of Chile, officially known as the president of the Republic of Chile is the head of state and head of government of Chile. The president is responsible for both the Chilean government and state administration. Although its role and significance has changed over the history of Chile, as well as its position and relations with other actors in the national political organization, it is

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Bryant, English historian and journalist (b. 1899)

entities.title: Arthur Bryant
entities.description: Sir Arthur Wynne Morgan Bryant, was an English historian, columnist for The Illustrated London News and man of affairs. His books included studies of Samuel Pepys, accounts of English eighteenth- and nineteenth-century history, and a life of George V. Whilst his scholarly reputation has declined somewhat since his death, he continues to be read and to be the subject of detailed historical studies.

heading: Deaths
txt: R. Budd Dwyer, American educator and politician, 30th Treasurer of Pennsylvania (b. 1939)

entities.title: R. Budd Dwyer
entities.description: Robert Budd Dwyer was an American politician who served as the 30th State Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. He served from 1965 to 1971 as a Republican member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and from 1971 to 1981 as a member of the Pennsylvania State Senate representing the state's 50th district. Dwyer then served as the 30th Treasurer of Pennsylvania from January 20, 198

entities.title: Pennsylvania Treasurer
entities.description: The Pennsylvania State Treasurer is the head of the Pennsylvania Treasury Department, an independent department of state government. The state treasurer is elected every four years. Treasurers are limited to two consecutive terms.

heading: Deaths
txt: S. Vithiananthan, Sri Lankan author and academic (b. 1924)

entities.title: S. Vithiananthan
entities.description: Professor Suppiramaniam Vithiananthan was a Sri Lankan writer, academic and the first vice-chancellor of the University of Jaffna.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Choquette, Canadian author, poet and diplomat (b. 1905)

entities.title: Robert Choquette
entities.description: Robert Guy Choquette was a Canadian novelist, poet and diplomat.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kōbō Abe, Japanese playwright and photographer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Kōbō Abe
entities.description: Kōbō Abe , pen name of Kimifusa Abe , was a Japanese writer, playwright, musician, photographer and inventor. Abe has been often compared to Franz Kafka and Alberto Moravia for his modernist sensibilities and his surreal, often nightmarish explorations of individuals in contemporary society.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Louis Barrault, French actor and director (b. 1910)

entities.title: Jean-Louis Barrault
entities.description: Jean-Louis Barrault was a French actor, director and mime artist who worked on both screen and stage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Telly Savalas, American actor (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Israel Eldad, Polish-Israeli philosopher and author (b. 1910)

entities.title: Israel Eldad
entities.description: Israel Eldad, was an Israeli Revisionist Zionist philosopher and member of the Jewish underground group Lehi in Mandatory Palestine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy Mackenzie, Scottish singer-songwriter (b. 1957)

entities.title: Billy Mackenzie
entities.description: William MacArthur Mackenzie was a Scottish singer and songwriter, known for his distinctive high tenor voice. He was the co-founder and lead singer of post-punk and new wave band the Associates. He also had a brief solo career releasing his debut album, Outernational, in 1992, his only solo album released during his lifetime.

heading: Deaths
txt: Graham Staines, Australian-Indian missionary and translator (b. 1941)

entities.title: Graham Staines
entities.description: Graham Stuart Staines was an Australian Christian missionary, who along with his two sons, Philip and Timothy, was burnt to death in India by members of a Hindu fundamentalist group named Bajrang Dal. In 2003, Bajrang Dal activist Dara Singh was convicted of leading the murderers and was sentenced to life in prison.

heading: Deaths
txt: Craig Claiborne, American journalist, author, and critic (b. 1920)

entities.title: Craig Claiborne
entities.description: Craig Claiborne was an American restaurant critic, food journalist and book author. A long-time food editor and restaurant critic for The New York Times, he was also the author of numerous cookbooks and an autobiography. Over the course of his career, he made many contributions to gastronomy and food writing in the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne Hébert, Canadian author and poet (b. 1916)

heading: Deaths
txt: Tommie Agee, American baseball player (b. 1942)

entities.title: Tommie Agee
entities.description: Tommie Lee Agee was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a center fielder from 1962 through 1973, most notably as a member of the New York Mets team that became known as the Miracle Mets when, they rose from being perennial losers to defeat the favored Baltimore Orioles in the 1969 World Series for one of the most improbable upsets in World Series history

heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Brown, American clown and puppeteer (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Mauldin, American soldier and cartoonist (b. 1921)

entities.title: Bill Mauldin
entities.description: William Henry Mauldin was an American editorial cartoonist who won two Pulitzer Prizes for his work. He was most famous for his World War II cartoons depicting American soldiers, as represented by the archetypal characters Willie and Joe, two weary and bedraggled infantry troopers who stoically endure the difficulties and dangers of duty in the field. His cartoons were popular with soldiers throug

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy May, American trumpet player and composer (b. 1916)

entities.title: Billy May
entities.description: Edward William May Jr. was an American composer, arranger and trumpeter. He composed film and television music for The Green Hornet (1966), The Mod Squad (1968), Batman, and Naked City (1960). He collaborated on films such as Pennies from Heaven (1981), and orchestrated Cocoon, and Cocoon: The Return, among others.

txt: Tom Mead, Australian journalist and politician (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths

entities.title: César Gutiérrez
entities.description: César Dario Gutiérrez [goo-te-er'-rez], also nicknamed "Cocoa", was a Venezuelan professional baseball player. He played as a shortstop in Major League Baseball for the San Francisco Giants in the 1967 and 1969 seasons, and for the Detroit Tigers from 1969 to 1971. Listed at 5'9" and 155 lbs, he batted and threw right handed. Gutiérrez is notable for being the second player in Major League history

txt: Carlo Orelli, Italian soldier (b. 1894)

heading: Deaths
txt: Consuelo Velázquez, Mexican pianist and songwriter (b. 1924)

txt: Aydın Güven Gürkan, Turkish academic and politician, Turkish Minister of Labor and Social Security (b. 1941)
